8.text: The plan for 2017 is to raise more money

12.text:
and to spend more money
lending support to museums.

14.text: We want to be as responsive as we can

16.text: to the needs of the moment.

21.text:
The bread and butter of our work
is giving grants

24.text: for single works of art for acquisitions.

27.text:
Increasingly, we've become involved
in commissions,

30.text: for example, for the South London Gallery.

33.text:
We supported them with a major grant
for a garden by Gabriel Orozco.

37.text:
And, of course, those two great
moving image commissions

41.text: for St Paul's by Bill Viola

44.text:
happened as a result of
Art Fund intervention.

47.text:
Sometimes, we run public appeals to raise
very considerable sums of money.

52.text:
In the past year, the great Armada Portrait
of Elizabeth I was brought to Greenwich

58.text: in part through a public appeal.

61.text:
So our job is to assist museums
in whichever way is appropriate

66.text:
to acquire works of art
of whatever kind they want.

69.text:
We give grants that can be in millions
of pounds or simply hundreds of pounds.

75.text: We try to respond to the need as we find it.

77.text:
It can be anything from The Eagle comic
collection we helped the Atkinson buy,

82.text:
or the Egyptian artefacts
for the National Museums Scotland.

86.text:
The Art Fund helped us acquire two fragments
of a decorative Ancient Egyptian box.

92.text:
It's an incredible piece
of decorative woodwork

96.text:
and it's been incredible to have
the Art Fund's support to acquire it.

103.text:
Our job is to encourage curators
to think about the potential of objects

109.text:
to unlock  a new way of thinking
about the world.

113.text: Our New Collecting Awards were designed

116.text:
to pick out some
of the most talented young curators

119.text: to learn about what acquisition making is.

122.text:
Charlotte Keenan, for example,
at the Walker Art Gallery in Liverpool,

128.text: She installed a very complex work —

131.text:
John Walter's Alien Sex Club,
which had a huge impact on its audience.

137.text:
In Blackpool, Richard Parry wanted
to collect works related to light.

142.text:
He made a major acquisition of a work
by Tracey Emin through the scheme.

147.text:
We are entering the third year
of the New Collecting Awards scheme.

150.text:
We have raised over £1 million from other
sources beyond our acquisitions funding,

156.text:
so this is a big growth area
for the Art Fund.

162.text:
The Museum of the Year
is about shining a light on a sector

166.text: which we think is important for Britain

169.text:
and perhaps particularly important at
the moment, with so much uncertainty ahead.

173.text:
We're encouraging everyone
to throw their hats into the ring

176.text:
and we'll see what
the 2017 shortlist looks like.

180.text:
British museums are admired the world over.
They do encourage reflection.

187.text: They are instruments of great creativity.

190.text:
Art and museums do have the power,
not just to transport us

194.text:
away from the difficult realities
of the moment,

197.text:
but to give us hope
and a vision of some kind of a future.

201.text:
When you go round and see the way
in which each one of these institutions

207.text: with the idea of what a museum can be,

209.text:
it gives you a sense of the power
of museums, the potential of museums.

214.text:
Each museum has had this blossoming,
so that's what we're looking for —

219.text:
they have something new
to offer to the audience.

222.text:
It gives me enormous pleasure
to announce the winner for 2016.

230.text:
In 2017, I think we're going to make
some great acquisitions.

234.text:
I hope we're going to make it possible
for thousands more people

238.text:
to visit museums
through the National Art Pass.

240.text:
I hope we're going to see
some great artist commissions

243.text:
and I think we're going to see a great
museum crowned as Museum of the Year 2017.
